The Cabinet discussed the measures to be taken to obtain reparation for the murder of Dr. Mauchamp. The cruisers Jeanne d'Arc and have started for Morocco. (R )
The Moroccan situation is regarded with some anxiety in France.
Xhe tone of the Qerman and French press in discussing the various recent incidents is increasingly acrimonious.
The Cabinet has decided to occupy Ujda, near the Algerian frontier, pending satisfaction being given for the murder of Dr. Mauchamp. (Reuter)
The Council of Ministers has decided to occupy Ujda until Morocco gives the reparation demanded. ( Havas)
The cruisers Jeanne d'Arc and Lalande have left for Tangier.

The Nicaraguans have seized Choluteca, which the Hondurans and San Salvadoreans held. The President Bonilla embarked on a vessel and escaped. Steamers have started in pursuit
The Nicaraguans have fought several sharp battles with the Hondurans and San Salvadorians, who have Been uniformly beaten. The causes which led to the war remain unexplained

The disturbances are ascribable to a huge trust holding 3,188,000 acres which sub-lets to peasants at exorbitant rents. 2,000 peasants attacked a company of soldiers in the village of Bachi armed with revolvers and rifles. The troops were outnumbered and retired after firing and killing 40 peasants and wounding many others. (Reuter

div.head: Gordon Cup Semi Finals
div.p: The semi finals of this polo tournament were played at Ghezireh on Saturday afternoon. 'I he two excellent matches were witnessed by a large gathering, the interest being sustained to the end

div.head: First Match
div.p: These teams started level, each having a handicap of + 6 goals from scratch. The game was of a most interesting character, the teams being wonderfully level. The Civilians were at a disadvantage in having no "skipper," hence their combination was bad They certain ly had the best of the game. Major Pirie was however a tower ofs rength; his skill in defence won the match for his side, but not until »n extra chukker was Htarted, as at the call of time no goal had been scored by either side. Final score : K.S.C, I goal; Civilians niL

div.head: Second Match
div.p: An excellent and very fast game, the Staff winning by two goals.

First chukker the Dragoons played up well and the Staff had only registered -1 goal when the bell rang. Score: Dragoons, 7; Staff ] SECOND CHUKKER.—Dragoons seemed to lose their dash, Capt. Dunbar and Bartlett getting away time after time quickly added 3 goals Score, half time : Staff 4. Dragoons 7 THIRD CHUKKER —Capt. Bartlett was very conspicuous in this period, his meeting the ball and near side forward strokes being brilliant. Three more goals weie added by the Staff' and at commencement of last chukker score was 7 all.
The Dragoons then pulled tbemselvus together and pla\ed up hard. There was however no stopping Capt. Dunbar and Bartlett who, adding one goal each, won the match.
Final score : Staff 9 goals Dragoons 7 goals.

div.head: Gordon Cup Finals
div.p: The finals of this popular tournament were played yesterd *y before a large gathering of spectators. The Staff an l Departmental were the favourites, but the K.S C. te im put up an unexpectedly stubborn resistance, and even succeeded in adding two goals to their handicap. Major Pirie, practically doing all this work himself, refused to own defeat until the call of time.

div.head: Helouan Sporting Club
div.p: At a meeting of the committee of the H.S.C., held at He'ouan on Thursday last week, the accounts for the past racing reason were submitted by the Hon. Treasurer and approved. They shewed a very satisfactory condition of affairs, which augurs well for the future of this club. Nearly £i,500 were given in stake-* during the p;ist seas »n and practically the whole of this sum was covered by the entries, the lotteries and the receipts fr *m the gate and Pari Mutuel It will be remembered that during the s^a^on just ended on two occasions the stakes figured £300 for each race. It was decided, however, at this meeting of the committee to increase these stakes for the next winter season and to offer £500 in stakes for the Tewfik Plate and £500 for the Élelouan Derby, and, besides to m.ke two m ire races of £100 each for the 3rd Winter Race Meeting, i.e., The Maiden Pony Rice and the Maiden Horse Race of £100 each. We co-.gratulate the very energetic committee on their great success, for we are safe in saying that no club was begun under greater difficulties than this one and none in this co ntry has in such a short time become better known or patronized or more firmly established. The programme oi the principal events for next wMon will shortly be published

div.head: Womens Broken Health
Dr. Williams Pink Pills
div.p: women will appreciate how severe was the trial qf Mrs. Jessie Henderson, 1224, Spring- bum place, Glasgow. To-day she states that store of strength she found in Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale people. "Some time after the birth of my youngest child," Mrs. Henderson stated, "my health rapidly gave way until it broke down entirely. Instead of regaining my u*ual strength, I was dismayed to find that I remained in a low, weak state that became more and- more pronounced. "I was quite unfit to do anything in the house, and the doctor who had attended me said my system Was completely run-down, and that all my troubles were due to Aggravated bloodlessness I tried to get my strength up - by plenty of nourishment, but I simply could not take anything in the shape of food. Everything disagreed with me ; if I did venture to eat a little I suffered agonies of indigestion. "In addition painful boils broke out all over my body, and I gradually went from bad to worse. What with shortness of breath, palpitation and other ailments, I feared my children would soon be motherless. I was so terribly weak that on going upstairs I had to sit down and rest several times before I could reach the top. "My legs seemed as though they could not support my body, and once when I got out of bed I staggered and fell on the floor, remaining there helpless until I was carried back to bed. I ate nothing, and people wondered how I kept alive. You oan easily imagine what all this meant to me. In my weak state I was quite unable to sit up and do my sewing, and my back seemed to be breaking, and lights danced before my eyes so that I could not see what I was doing Worn away to skin and bone, I gave myself up as lost. \ 'It was just when all hope seemed gone that Dr. Williams' Pink -Pills for Pale People were recommended to me, and thankful I am I tried them, for they saved my life. It was a girl friend of mine who told me about them, and said they had effected a wonderful cure in a cose known to her. "Although I had no great faith in any medicine by this time, I bought a box of the pills, and after a time I frit that they wore doing mo some good. I was soon able to digest food, and my appetite improved every day. The boils began to disappear as my blood was enriched by the pills, and before very long my skin was dear I was no longer troubled with palpitation, and could run upstairs without ( getting out of breath. I continued to use Dr. Williams' Pink Pills until the change was so great in me that I needed them no more. Now j I can sew as long as I like without feeling fatigued. In fact, my health is fully restored and quite as good as it ever has been. I feel certain that Dr. Williams' Pink Pills saved me from certain death " When the Blood becomes thin and weak the nerves lose "tone" and the system rapidly breaks down. Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People ensure good health by making Good, Rich Blood in abundance and feeding the starved nerves In both sexs they have cured An»mia, General Weakness, Influenza's After-effects, Indigestion, Eczema, Rheumatism, Sciatica, Neuralgia, St Vitus' Dance, rv Nervous \\ and Paralysis. div.head: Circulaire fl. De Vries et Boutlgn;
div.p: Le Caire. Samedi 23 Mara 1907. Le taux de l'esoompte libre à L mdrea reste à 5%. Oa s'attendrait à an abaissement dans le coarant de la semaine prochaine par snite de l'amélioration marquante qai oontinqe à se produire à New-York. En attendant, le bilan hebdomadaire de la Banque l'Angleterre,publié ayant-hier, montre que la proportion de la réserve aux engagements est descendue de 4$ 3/8 à 44 poor oant. D'autre part, par suite de la tension monétaire, le taux d'escompte ft Paris a été élevé de 3 d 3 1/2 pour cent. Aa Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a rétrogradé hier ds 1/8 à 8$ 1/4. L'Uuifié9 a perda 1/4 à 1011/2. La National B*. k a enoore reculé de 1/8 à 26 1/2. L'Agricole «est maintenue ft 9, de mémnqae la D. ïra à 15 3/4 et la Dalta Light à 10 7/8. A Paris, le Oré lit Foncier Egyptien est dsmsuré inchangé à 736. La Ba que d A hè ies a progressé de 1 frano à 132. Dans son ensemb'e, la séance d'aojoard'hui de notre marché a été plas oa moins la reproduction de celle d'hier. Accalmie et lonrdear sar tonte la ligne, trois titres qai ont Onannonoe officiellement qne M. Reginald porter de graves atteintes anx meilleure* va- Heuriques, delà maison Heurquei et Henri- leurs locales, lesqnelles n ont rien ft démêfar que?, vient d'ôtre nommé directeur général de avA° 00 Q '* P*'0!' 80 Pa8*0* de 1 autre oôté de l'Bgyptiau Delta Ltnd and Iuvestmeut Co. div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: LAKE OF LUCERNE. Grand Hotel, Axen-Fels.
div.p: Best Spring resort. 2,200 ft. above the sea. Every comfort.

The leading Hotel for English and American families. Trains every fifteen minutes by Electric Railway from Brunnen to Axen-Fels. The Park having a frontage of nearly a mile on the lake, is one of the prettiest in Switzerland.
World-wide reputation.
P: Sohnack, Proprietor
Level Wooded Walks.

div.head: GRAND HOTEL DES BAINS.
div.p: Adjoining the sea. First-class hotel with dependencies & chalets. 200 rooms & saloons. Electric light. Aqueduct. Every modern comfort. Delightful residence, without any mosquitos.

div.head: THE GRAND HOTEL LIDO.
div.p: Hotel with its dependencies (Swiss Hotel), in the most delightful situation of the Lido at the landing place, five minutes walk from the bathing place. Wonderful view of the Legune of Venice. Room from 3 lire, with board from 8.50 per day. No mosquitos. Very dry and safe air.
Address- SOCIETE BACHI, LIDO, VENICE, ITALY.

div.head: St. Moritz (Engadine) Switzerland. The Grand Hotel St. Moritz.
div.p: A new first class hotel with every modern convenience.
Address all inquiries to THE MANAGER.

div.head: LAKE OF COMO (Cernobble.) GRAND HOTEL VILLA D'ESTE
div.p: First-class hotel, finest situation on the Lake. Immense park and garden. Moderate charges. Omnibus at Como station.
T. Domben, Manager.

div.head: COMO "PLINIUS" GRAND HOTEL,
div.p: On the border of the Lake with beautfiul Garden and large Terraces. Magnificent Palace, built for the purpose of an Hotel, with the most complete comfort. Opened March, 1899. Very reasonable prices. English church.
Proprietor: J. De Glacomi, Manager of Gd. Hotel Neues Stahibad, St. Moritz, Engadine, Switzerland.
Manager: C. Scrobbi, of Neues Stahibad, St. Moritz.

div.head: LUGANO (Lake of Lugane) GRAND HOTEL METROPOLE ET MONOPOLE.
div.p: STRICTLY FIRST CLASS.
A BROCCA, Proprietor.
Also of the GRAND HOTEL, LUGANO.

div.head: LOCARNO THE GRAND HOTEL.
div.p: OPEN ALL THE YEAR.

Strictly first class. Every modern comfort. Terminus of the St. Gothard Railway. Magnificent winter and spring Resort. Best stopping place on the Italian lakes. Beautiful walks excursion English Chruch. Tennis and Golf. Central Heating.

div.head: LUCERNE HOTEL DE L'EUROPE
div.p: Comfortable family hotel, charmingly situated, known for its quietness, Extensive view of Lake and Mountain scenery. Newly furnished, every modern comfort, lift, electric light, throughout, grand hall and covered terraces, beautiful garden, table d'Hotel at small tables, moderate terms.
New proprietors, Blorn Bros.

div.head: Hotel TIVOLI pension.
div.p: Beautiful situation overlooking the Lake.
FIRST CLASS.
Every modern comfort
Moderate charges.

div.head: INNSBRUCK (Tyrol) CARL KAISER'S PENSION-HOTEL
div.p: Splendid situation, overlooking river and valley, surrounded by fruit, conifer and rose gardens, modern comforts and home-like, Library, English and American papers, baths, carriages, good Table and sanitary arrangements.

Specially suitable for those requiring rest, quietness, and change of air. Capital headquarters for excursions. Post telegraph, telephone, dark room, terms moderate for either short or long stay. English spoken. Apply for prospectus.

div.head: INTERLAKEN Regina Hotel,
div.p: JUNGFRAUBLICK.
Unrivalled position. FIRST CLASS. Thoroughly renovated suites and rooms with private baths.
Central heating. Every modern comfort.
J. Oesch.
Proprietor and Manager.

div.head: CHATEAU D'OEX THE GRAND HOTEL.
div.p: The newesty and most up-to-date, thoroughly First Class and replete with every modern comfort.
ELECRTIC LIGHT, CENTRAL HEATING, PRIVATE BATHS.

div.head: HOTEL BERTHOD.
div.p: The most comfortable first class family hotel.
EVERY MODERN COMFORT.
Berthod Brothers Proprietors.

div.head: ATHENS HOTEL DE LA GRANDE BRETAGNE
div.p: Special Office in the Hotel for Railway and Steamship
Tickets: also Post Office.
E. Lampsa, proprietor.

div.head: TOURIST AGENCY. POLEMY BROS., ATHENS.
div.p: 2. Philellenic Street (corner of Constitution Square), Conducted Tours for visiting Greece, Ionian Islands, Islands of the Archipelago, Asia Minor, Turkey, Palestine and Egypt.

div.head: CORFU GRAND HOTEL D'ANGLETERRE ET BELLE VENISE
div.p: Only first-class Hotel in Corfu with magnificent Garden. Fashionable modern Family Hotel. View of the Sea and lovely landscapes. Quietest, healthiest, and highest situation. Is the only Hotel situation in the highest part of Corfu.
Jean Garru and Freen, Proprietors.

div.head: Clayton Gas Company of Egypt and the Sudan
div.p: Incorporated under the Companies Acts 1862 to 1900).

The profits of the Company available for dividend in each Financial Year shall be applicable as follows :— Firstly .—In carrying 5 per cent, thereof to reserve. Secondly :—In paying a dividend at the rate of 5 per cent, per annum to the holders of the Ordinary Shares in the Capital of the Company on the amounts paid or credited as paid up thereon. * * Thirdly :—Out of the residue of the said profits there shall be paid to the Directors an amount equal to 5 per cent, thereof and the balance shall belong as to one half thereof to the holders of the Ordinary Shares and as to the other half thereof to the holders of the Founders Shares. On a distribution of the assets on the Liquidation of the Company the assets remaining after payment of the liabilities shall be applied first in repaying the Capital paid or credited as paid up on the Ordinary Shares and thereafter shall be divided as to one half among the holders of the Ordinary Shares and as to the other half among the holders of the Founders Shares. Issue of 15,000 Ordinary Scares of £ 1 each at par for Public Subscription. Founders Shares of 1/- each will be offered for Subscription to persons who have applied for and had allotted to them Ordinary Shares in the proportion of One Founders Share for every ten Ordinary Shares. The balance of Ordinary and Founders' Shares will be dealt with In manner hereinafter mentioned. No application for less than ten Ordinary Shares will be considered : The following payments shall be made on the Ordinary Shares :— 10/- per 8hare on Application 10/- per 8hare on Allotment
DIRECTORS

ASTLEY P. FRIEND M I.C.E., Manager Cairo Water Works, Cairo, Egypt (Chairman). A. J. TWEED®E, Merchant, Port-Saïd, Egypt. T. A. CLAYTON (President of the Sulphur Diôxide Fumigating and Fire Extinguishing. Company, p. S. A 20, Rue Taitbout, Paris. F, MACKINNON, Engineer, Maison Mesciaca, Sharia Kasr-el-Nil, Cairo, Egypt.. (Managing Director).

div.head: Prospecturs
div.p: The Company has been formed to acquire the solo rights for Egypt and the Sudan of the Clayton Process—the several uses of which may be briefly described : — 1. (a) For Preventing and extinguishing fire on board ship by rapidly generating "Clayton Gas" and forcing it under pressure into the hold or compartment to be protected, (b) and reducing the temperature of the hold or compartment in which a fire has been extinguished by circulating the gas-laden atmosphere through the cooler, (c) and by the same process reducing the temperature caused by the heating of any cargo. 2 For Fumigating and Disinfecting, by charging any compartment with "Clayton Gas' of sufficient strength to be germicidal. It has been proved that this Gas has no injurious effect on any dry material, and the baccili of plague, cholera, yellow' fever, diphtheria, and typhoid are among those that have been destroyed in actual fumigations by this system. "Clayton Gas" also sterilizes the infection of smallpox. 3. For Preventing heating of Cereals, either in warehouses or ships'holds, by applying a sufficient strength of "Glayton Gas" to sterilize the ferment germ, without affecting the germinating properties of the grain. 4 For Exterminating rats, insects and all vermin, such as cockroaches, bugs, fleas, ants, weevil, etc., that infest ships, warehouses and stores Rats so destroyed come out of their holes in search of air as soon as the pungent gas reaches them, and can therefore be collected and disposed of without difficulty, the risk of leaving dead vermin toputrify undiscovered being thereby avoided. "Clayton Gas" destroys not only rats and vermin, but the parasites on them, and also sterilizes the eggs of insects. With regard to its use for Fumigation, Prevention of and extinguishing fire on Vessels, it is worthy of note that the system has been adopted by the Norddeutscher Lloyd, The Ham' burg-America Line, The Union Steam Ship Co. of New Zealand, the Pacific Mail S.S Co. New-York, the Adam S.S. Co. Ltd Aberdeen. The Cie Sud American de Vapores, Valparaiso the Pacific Steam Navigation Co., Liverpool, The British India Steam Navigation Company, The Nippon Yusen Kaisha Co, fokio, and many other shipping Lines too numerous to mention in this prospectus. The importance of the Clayton system is recognised by the leading Insurance Companies and L nder-W riters, who discriminate in favour of vessels equipped with it, and, in numerous iustances, accept risks at a reduction of premium provided the Clayton Appaiatus is installed Fumigat om avd disinfection. — Dr. Calmette, Director of the Pasteur Institute at Lille recommends the general adoption of the Clayton System at all QuarantineStations with a view to the amelibration of existing Quarantine regulations and as an effective means of preventing the introduction of infectious diseases. Its adoption by the French Colonial Service, the Crown Agents for the Colonies, the Governments of South Africa, Chili, Péru, Ecuador, etc., affords sufficient evidence of the value of the system. Its value for the disinfection of Hospitals, Stables, etc , has also been most successfully proved to the satisfaction of many of the leading European Doctors With regard to Stables, at the Stud Farm of Val d'Enfer an epidemic of malignant glanders was completely stamped out, and the system has been adopted at the Stud Farm of Chantilly,Jardy (M. JSdmond Blanc), by the Duc de Gramont, — in several large cab yards of Paris — notably that of Messrs. Radlaner where an attack of contagious pneumonia was entirely stamped out For the prevention of the heating of cereals and the extermination of rats, all vermin and insects, so numerous are the ample proofs of the complete efficiency of the Clayton system that space is this prospectus does not permit of the publication in it of the many testimonials from Expert Authorities, but they may be inspected at the Company's Office at any time It is difficult to mention a country where a larger scope exists for the exploitation of the Clayton Gas System than in Egypt and the Sudan The qualification of each Director is the holding of Shares or Stock of the Company of the nominal value of £200. The provisions in the Articles of Association relating to the remuneration of the Director! areas follows : {*jjEhe Directors shall be paid out of the funds of the Company by way of remuneration " for tlîèir services the sum of £600 per annum, of which £200 shall be paid to the Chairman " and the balance be dividend among the remaining Directors. The percentage of profit " hereinbefore mentioned, together with any extra remuneration that may at any time be " v^ted to the Directors by the Company in General Meeting, shall be divided among the " Direct* *rs in such proportions and manner as they by agreement may determine, or in " default of agreement equally. " If any Director shall be called upon the perform extra or special services of any kind, " or to travel or to go or reside abroad for any business or purposes of the Company, he shall " be entitled to receive such sum as the Board may think fit, fo; expenses of living and " entertaining, and also such remuneration as the Board think fit, either as a fixed sum or as a " percentage of profits or otherwise, and such remuneration may, as the Board shall determine, " be either in addition to or in substitution for any other remuneration he may be entitled to 4' receive, and the same shall be charged as part of the ordinary working expenses. " The remuneration of a Managing Director shall from time to time be fixed by the " Directors, and may be by way of salary or commission or participation in the profits or by " any or all of those modes, and shall, if so determined by the Board, be in addii ion to any remuneration payable to the Directors or to the Managing Director as one of the Directors " under these presents.'' The following Contracts have been entered into, viz :— , (1) An Agreement dated 31 st January, 1907, between The Sulphur Dioxide Fumigating and Fire Extinguishing Company, of New York, U.S.A. (hereinafter called the Vendors), and Alfred Curphey, of Cairo, Egypt, providing for the formation of the Company. (2) An Agretment dated 13th March, 1907, between the Vendors and the Company providing for the sale to the Company of the Clayton Patents for Egypt and the Sudan, in consideration of the allotment to the Vendors of 26,000 Ordinary Shares of £1 each as fully paid up, and the right to subscribe at par for 4,260 Founders' Shares of 1 -each. (3) An Agreement dated 13th March, 1907, between the said Alfred Curphey and the Company, whereby the said Alfred Curphey (inter alia) agrees : — (a) To apply for and have alloted to him at par 10,000 Orrdinary Shares of £1 each. (b) To procure to be subscribed at par 15,000 further Ordinary Shares of £1 each. (c) To pay all expenses of and incidental to the formation and promotion of the Company other than underwriting commissions, stamps on share warrants and broket ages. And the Company in consideration thereof inter alia) agrees : (a) To pay to the said Alfred Curphey a sum not exceeding £2,000 in respect of his expenses in connection with the promotion of the Company. (b) To allot to the said Alfred Curphey at par 4,250 Founders' Shares of l/-each. (c) To issue at its own expense a Prospectus offering for public subscription 15,000 Ordinary Shares of £1 each at par on the terms herein set forth and to pay the brokerage of 6d. per Share below mentioned. ; Save as above-mentioned no Underwriting Commission is being paid on this issue. Mr. T. A. Clayton, one of,the Directors is interested in the promotion of the Company to the extent of his holding in The Sulphur Dioxide Fumigating and Fire Extinguishing Company of 6,250 shares out of a total of 20,000 shares. The amount of the preliminary expenses is estimated at £2,000. Application for Shares should be made on the accompanying form and forwarded to | the Company's Bankers with a cheque for the amount payable on application. If no allotment * is made the application money will be returned in full and where the number of shares allotted is less than that applied for the surplus will be credited in reduction of the amount payable on allotment and any excess will be returned to the applicant. Failure to pay any instalment when due will render the previous payments liable to be forfeited. Share Warrants to bearer will be issued in exchange for fully p«*.id allotment letters as soon as they are ready, of which due notice will be given. A copy of the Memorandum of Association which forms part of this Prospectus is endorsed hereon The minimum subscription upon which the Directors will proceed to allotment is £15,000. A brokerage of sixpence per Share will be paid to Brokers on all Shares applied for and allotted to the Public on application forms bearing the stamps and the name and address of Brokers whose Clients are subscribing. A print of the Memorandum and Articles of Association of the Company and the Contracts referred to may be inspected at the Offices of Maitre L. Carton de Wiart,Cairo Copies of the Prospectus and application forms can be obtained at the Local Offices of the Company and from the Company's Bankers. Dated the 20th March 1907.
